partial_orders.reason: Edit 1 removes the 'client_id' parameter from the api_update_pointer function signature and removes the @has_request_variables decorator that was extracting it from POST data. Edit 0 removes the 'client_id' field from the test data being sent to this same API endpoint. These edits reference the exact same parameter ('client_id') in the same API function - one edit removes it from the function signature/parameter extraction, and the other removes it from the test data calling that function. This creates a direct code dependency where both edits are part of the same refactoring to remove the client_id parameter entirely. Either edit can be made first without causing parse errors, making this bi-directional.

Edit 0 removes the 'pointer_updater' parameter from the function signature of update_pointer, and Edit 1 removes the same parameter from a call to that exact same function. These edits reference the exact same symbol (the update_pointer function) and form a signature-caller relationship. After making either edit, the other becomes the immediate next step to maintain code consistency - if you change the signature without updating the call site, you get a TypeError at runtime, and vice versa. Both edits can be written and parsed in either order since Python allows mismatched function signatures and calls at parse time (only failing at runtime), making this bi-directional rather than ordered.

Edit 0 removes the `updater` parameter from the call in `api_update_pointer`, while Edit 1 removes the `request.session.session_key` parameter from the call in `json_update_pointer`. This represents a bulk-edit pattern where identical structural changes (parameter removal) are being applied to multiple call sites of the same function. Either edit could be made first without causing parse errors, and both are part of the same contiguous refactoring task.
